Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates wearing festival wreath headdress with two lotus buds and his right index finger to his mouth. Mould-made and hollow. White (gypsum) coating. Brown Nile silt fabric with red-brown core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis, with 1st to 2nd century BC parallel in the British Museum (Bailey 2008, no.3046). '18' written on back in pencil. An unprovenanced parallel has been dated to the late Ptolemaic period (Török 1995, no.89, see also 84). Török, L. 1995, Hellenistic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Roma.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.055) (Phase 1)
